    195. 195
      Rasmussen, L. M.; Zaveri, N. T.; Stenvang, J.; Peters, R. H.; Lykkesfeldt, A. E. A novel dual-target steroid sulfatase inhibitor and antiestrogen: SR 16157, a promising agent for the therapy of breast cancer Breast Cancer Res. Treat. 2007, 106, 191– 203
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      195
      A novel dual-target steroid sulfatase inhibitor and antiestrogen: SR 16157, a promising agent for the therapy of breast cancer
      Rasmussen, Louise M.; Zaveri, Nurulain T.; Stenvang, Jan; Peters, Richard H.; Lykkesfeldt, Anne E.
      Breast Cancer Research and Treatment (2007), 106 (2), 191-203CODEN: BCTRD6; ISSN:0167-6806. (Springer)
      Endocrine therapy is the ideal treatment choice for estrogen receptor α (ERα)-pos. breast cancer patients. Principal used therapies target either the ERα e.g. by selective ERα modulators (SERMs) such as tamoxifen or target estrogen biosynthesis with aromatase inhibitors. Steroid sulfatase (STS) plays a crucial role in formation of compds. with estrogenic properties, converting inactive sulfate-conjugated steroids to active non-conjugated forms. Steroid sulfates are considered as a reservoir for active steroids due to their prolonged half-life and increased concn. in plasma. STS is present in several tissues including the breast, and the STS the mRNA level and enzyme activity is significantly increased in ERα-pos. breast tumors. Inhibition of STS is therefore a new approach for decreasing estrogenic steroids that stimulate breast cancer. The novel dual-acting compd. SR 16157 is designed as a sulfamate-contg. STS inhibitor that releases a tissue-selective SERM SR 16137. Use of a dual-target STS inhibitor and SERM represents a new strategy in the treatment of hormone-dependent breast cancer. In this study, we tested the potential of SR 16157 and SR 16137 on STS activity, cell growth and ERα function in MCF-7 breast cancer cells. We confirmed that the dual-target compd. SR 16157 exerts STS inhibition and antiestrogenic effects. SR 16157 was a highly effective growth inhibitor, being 10 times more potent than the antiestrogens SR 16137 and tamoxifen. Relative to tamoxifen, SR 16137 displays profoundly improved ERα binding affinity and antiestrogenic effects on expression of estrogen-regulated genes. Thus, the dual-target SR 16157 is possibly a promising new treatment alternative, superior to tamoxifen.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXht1CgtL7O&md5=da8c8215112ce62e4830ab559845e73c
    196. 196
      Rausch, L.; Green, C.; Steinmetz, K.; LeValley, S.; Catz, P.; Zaveri, N.; Schweikart, K.; Tomaszewski, J.; Mirsalis, J. Preclinical pharmacokinetic, toxicological and biomarker evaluation of SR16157, a novel dual-acting steroid sulfatase inhibitor and selective estrogen receptor modulator Cancer Chemother. Pharmacol. 2011, 67, 1341– 1352
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      196
      Preclinical pharmacokinetic, toxicological and biomarker evaluation of SR16157, a novel dual-acting steroid sulfatase inhibitor and selective estrogen receptor modulator
      Rausch, Linda; Green, Carol; Steinmetz, Karen; LeValley, Sue; Catz, Paul; Zaveri, Nurulain; Schweikart, Karen; Tomaszewski, Joseph; Mirsalis, Jon
      Cancer Chemotherapy and Pharmacology (2011), 67 (6), 1341-1352CODEN: CCPHDZ; ISSN:0344-5704. (Springer)
      SR16157 is a novel dual-acting inhibitor of estrogen action that irreversibly inhibits the estrogen biosynthetic enzyme steroid sulfatase (STS) and releases the selective estrogen receptor modulator SR16137, which blocks the estrogen receptor. SR16157 is a promising agent for the endocrine therapy of breast cancer. We conducted preclin. in vivo toxicity evaluations to det. the max.-tolerated dose (MTD), target organ(s) of toxicity, reversibility, dose-limiting toxicity, no observable adverse effect level (NOAEL), and toxicokinetics (TK) and to investigate a potential biomarker for use in SR16157 clin. trials. SR16157 was administered to female Fischer 344 rats or beagle dogs by oral gavage (po) or capsule. I.v. groups were included for the detn. of bioavailability. Endpoints evaluated included clin. observations, body wts., hematol., serum chem., pharmacokinetics, TK, pathol. of tissues, and STS activity in liver, or peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs). For rats, the MTD (i.e., the highest dose that did not cause lethality but produced toxicity) was 33 mg/kg/day (198 mg/m2/day), and the NOAEL was <10 mg/kg/day (60 mg/m2/day). For dogs, the MTD was estd. to exceed 10 mg/kg/day (200 mg/m2/day), and the NOAEL was estd. to be at or above 2.5 mg/kg/day (50 mg/m2/day). Our studies demonstrate that SR16157 has excellent pharmacokinetic properties and an acceptable toxicol. profile. Modulation of STS activity in PBMCs appeared to be a possible biomarker for use in future clin. trials of SR16157.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXmsFGhsLo%253D&md5=d7d22f7a73ed1b857e27f003cac8449c

    199. 199
      Nakanishi, T.; Tamai, I. Putative roles of organic anion transporting polypeptides (OATPs) in cell survival and progression of human cancers Biopharm. Drug Dispos. 2014, 35, 463– 484
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      199
      Putative roles of organic anion transporting polypeptides (OATPs) in cell survival and progression of human cancers
      Nakanishi, Takeo; Tamai, Ikumi
      Biopharmaceutics & Drug Disposition (2014), 35 (8), 463-484CODEN: BDDID8; ISSN:0142-2782. (John Wiley & Sons Ltd.)
      A review. Transporter proteins classified into the solute carrier (SLC) transporter superfamily are essential for the import of nutrients required for cell survival in organisms. Various SLC transporters are differentially upregulated in cancer cells, and among them, polyspecific org. anion-transporting polypeptides (OATPs) have been proposed to have pathophysiol. significance in cancer. This review will briefly introduce OATPs and summarize their proposed roles in cancer, focusing particularly on hormone-dependent breast and prostate cancers. Over the past two decades, compelling evidence has also accumulated that SLC transporters, including OATPs, interact with clin. important anticancer agents and influence their pharmacokinetics, particularly the processes of absorption, elimination and distribution. Therefore, a better understanding of not only the pathophysiol. roles, but also the pharmacol. effects of OATPs in cancer cells should be helpful in combating human malignant tumors.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhvFWit7nK&md5=50a2231c94b2b7fa529f15537130ca5c
    200. 200
      Chura, J. C.; Blomquist, C. H.; Ryu, H. S.; Argenta, P. A. Estrone sulfatase activity in patients with advanced ovarian cancer Gynecol. Oncol. 2009, 112, 205– 209
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      200
      Estrone sulfatase activity in patients with advanced ovarian cancer
      Chura, Justin C.; Blomquist, Charles H.; Ryu, Hyung S.; Argenta, Peter A.
      Gynecologic Oncology (2009), 112 (1), 205-209CODEN: GYNOA3; ISSN:0090-8258. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Introduction: We sought to identify whether the sulfatase pathway was present in ovarian cancer specimens and then to det. whether a clin. correlation existed between sulfatase activity and survival. Materials and methods: Enzymic activity was assessed in advanced ovarian cancer specimens via thin layer chromatog. and standardized against total protein. All enzyme activities are reported in pmol/mg protein/30 min. Kaplan Meier curves of progression-free and overall survival were constructed to compare outcomes between patients with low sulfatase activity and high sulfatase activity. Median survival rates were compared using the log-rank test for survival curves. Differences in proportions between patients with low sulfatase activity vs. high sulfatase activity were compared with the z-test or chi-square anal. as appropriate. Results: 37 specimens from patients with advanced stage ovarian cancer were analyzed. Enzymic activity was detected in all specimens except one. Median progression-free survival was 23.5 mo for patients with low sulfatase activity compared to 6.9 mo for patients with high sulfatase activity (p = 0.008). Median overall survival favored the low sulfatase group (50.8 vs. 30.6 mo resp.), though statistical difference was not detected (p = 0.16). No other difference in clin. characteristics between patients with high or low sulfatase activity was detected. Conclusions: Sulfatase activity is widely present in ovarian cancer specimens. Increased sulfatase activity is assocd. with worse progression-free survival in patients with advanced stage ovarian cancer. The sulfatase pathway is a potential therapeutic target in the treatment of ovarian cancer.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhsFajsL7J&md5=66e78d0ff1f6e5cc7fd0dc7f5beb4fa4
    201. 201
      Kang, C. M.; Choe, Y. S.; Jung, K.-H.; Choi, J. Y.; Lee, K.-H.; Kim, B.-T. Synthesis and in vitro evaluation of 2-[11C] methoxyestradiol-3,17β-O,O-bissulfamate for in vivo studies of angiogenesis J. Labelled Compd. Radiopharm. 2011, 54, 783– 787
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      201
      Synthesis and in vitro evaluation of 2-[11C]methoxyestradiol-3,17β-O,O-bissulfamate for in vivo studies of angiogenesis
      Kang, Choong Mo; Choe, Yearn Seong; Jung, Kyung-Ho; Choi, Joon Young; Lee, Kyung-Han; Kim, Byung-Tae
      Journal of Labelled Compounds and Radiopharmaceuticals (2011), 54 (13), 783-787CODEN: JLCRD4; ISSN:0362-4803. (John Wiley & Sons Ltd.)
      In the present study, 2-methoxyestradiol-3,17β-O,O-bis-sulfamate (I), a known angiogenesis inhibitor, was prepd. in a radiolabeled form by 11C-methylation of 2-hydroxyestradiol-3,17β-O,O-bis(N-trityl)sulfamate (II) followed by detritylation. Synthesis of precursor II required a rather long step because of the presence of two sulfamoyl groups. The decay-cor. radiochem. yield of [11C]I was 19 ± 2% based on [11C]CH3I, and the specific activity was 34-39 GBq/μmol. Although I is known to significantly inhibit the proliferation of human umbilical vascular endothelial cells (HUVECs), its radiolabeled form, [11C]I was not avidly taken up by HUVECs, and the uptake increased slightly in a time-dependent manner (156% at 60 min relative to a value of 100% at 5 min). These results suggest that further studies are warranted to det. the mol. target for [11C]I. Copyright © 2011 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

      Wang, M.; Gao, M.; Miller, K. D.; Zheng, Q.-H. Synthesis of a new carbon-11-labelled sulfamate derivative as a potential PET tracer for imaging of breast cancer aromatase and steroid sulfatase expression Synth. Commun. 2011, 41, 1127– 1140
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      203
      Synthesis of a New Carbon-11-Labeled Sulfamate Derivative as a Potential PET Tracer for Imaging of Breast Cancer Aromatase and Steroid Sulfatase Expression
      Wang, Min; Gao, Mingzhang; Miller, Kathy D.; Zheng, Qi-Huang
      Synthetic Communications (2011), 41 (8), 1127-1140CODEN: SYNCAV; ISSN:0039-7911. (Taylor & Francis, Inc.)
      A carbon-11-labeled sulfamate deriv. was designed and synthesized as a new potential positron-emission-tomog. dual aromatase-steroid sulfatase inhibitor radiotracer for imaging of aromatase and steroid sulfatase expression in breast cancer. The target tracer 2-chloro-4-(((4-cyanophenyl)(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)amino)methyl)-6-[11C]methoxyphenyl sulfamate ([11C]7) was prepd. from its corresponding precursor 2-chloro-4-(((4-cyanophenyl)(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)amino)methyl)-6-hydroxyphenyl sulfamate (18) with [11C]CH3OTf under basic conditions through the O-[11C]methylation and isolated by the reversed-phase high-performance liq. chromatog. in 40-45% radiochem. yields based on [11C]CO2 and decay cor. to end of bombardment. The specific activity at end of synthesis was 111-185 GBq/μmol.

      2. 2
        Spinola, P. G.; Marchetti, B.; Ferand, L. Adrenal steroids stimulate growth and progesterone receptor levels in rat uterus and DMBA-induced mammary tumors Breast Cancer Res. Treat. 1986, 8, 241– 248
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2
        Adrenal steroids stimulate growth and progesterone receptor levels in rat uterus and DMBA-induced mammary tumors
        Spinola, Paulo G.; Marchetti, Bianca; Labrie, Fernand
        Breast Cancer Research and Treatment (1986), 8 (3), 241-8CODEN: BCTRD6; ISSN:0167-6806.
        The effects of treatment with the adrenal steroids androst-5-ene-3β,17β-diol (Δ5-diol) and dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) on the growth and progesterone receptor levels of dimethylbenz[a]anthracene (DMBA)-induced mammary tumors and uteri in the rat were studied. Although the total no. of tumors in ovariectomized animals was 0.60 tumor per rat after 24 days, it increased to 2.54 and 1.42 in the Δ5-diol- and DHEA (2 mg, twice daily)-treated animals, resp. Very few new tumors developed during a 24-day period in ovariectomized animals (0.07/rat), but an av. of 0.47 new tumor per animal appeared in intact rats. In ovariectomized animals treated with Δ5-diol or DHEA, the nos. of new tumors were 0.77 and 0.42, resp. An even more striking effect was obsd. on av. total tumor area, which decreased from 4.70 cm2 in intact animals to 0.75 cm2 following ovariectomy. Values of 9.79 and 3.93 cm2 were found in the Δ5-diol- and DHEA-treated ovariectomized animals, resp. Treatment of ovariectomized animals with Δ5-diol and DHEA increased progesterone receptor levels in both the uteri and DMBA-induced mammary tumors. Uterine wt. was also increased by treatment with the 2 adrenal steroids. Thus, 2 adrenal C19-Δ5 steroids, Δ5-diol and DHEA, possess stimulatory effects analogous to those of estrogens on DMBA-induced mammary tumor growth and progesterone receptor levels in the rat, which supports the suggestion of an important role of these adrenal steroids in breast cancer and other estrogen-sensitive diseases in the human.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL2sXltV2ls7g%253D&md5=fa34d6fe9a090224c667bff47daa07a1
      3. 3
        Komm, B. S.; Mirkin, S. An overview of current and emerging SERMs J. Steroid Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2014, 143, 207– 222
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3
        An overview of current and emerging SERMs
        Komm, Barry S.; Mirkin, Sebastian
        Journal of Steroid Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (2014), 143 (), 207-222CODEN: JSBBEZ; ISSN:0960-0760. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        A review. Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) are compds. that exhibit tissue-specific estrogen receptor (ER) agonist or antagonist activity, and are used for various indications, including treatment of breast cancer, osteoporosis, and menopausal symptoms. Endometrial safety has been a key differentiator between SERMs in clin. practice. For example, tamoxifen exhibits ER agonist activity in the uterus, resulting in an increased risk of endometrial hyperplasia and malignancy, whereas raloxifene and bazedoxifene have neutral effects on the uterus. Based on their efficacy and long-term safety, SERMs are increasingly being prescribed for women who cannot tolerate other treatment options and for younger women at an increased risk of fracture who may remain on therapy for long periods of time. Continuing advances in the understanding of SERM mechanisms of action and structural interactions with the ER may lead to the development of new agents and combinations of agents to provide optimal treatments to meet the varying needs of postmenopausal women. One such example is the tissue selective estrogen complex, which partners a SERM with 1 or more estrogens, with the aim of blending the desired estrogen-receptor agonist activities of estrogens on vasomotor symptoms, vulvar-vaginal atrophy, and loss of bone mass with the tissue selectivity of a SERM.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhsVaksrjK&md5=18074eedb314d30864441d3f57cc4880
      4. 4
        Santner, S. J.; Feil, P. D.; Santen, R. J. In situ estrogen production via the estrone sulfatase pathway in breast tumors: relative importance versus the aromatase pathway J. Clin. Endocrinol. Metab. 1984, 59, 29– 33
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4
        In situ estrogen production via the estrone sulfatase pathway in breast tumors: relative importance versus the aromatase pathway
        Santner, S. J.; Feil, P. D.; Santen, R. J.
        Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism (1984), 59 (1), 29-33CODEN: JCEMAZ; ISSN:0021-972X.
        Breast tumor estrogen prodn. via the estrone sulfate [481-97-0] to estrone [53-16-7] (i.e., estrone sulfatase [59298-96-3]) pathway was evaluated and compared with the androstenedione [63-05-8] to estrone (aromatase [9039-48-9]) system in human and rodent mammary tumors. Estrone prodn. from estrone sulfate was related linearly with time and tissue concns., exhibited an apparent Km of 20 μM, and produced a linear Eadie-Hofstee kinetic plot consistent with a single class of enzymic sites. Measurement of sulfatase in 35 human breast tumors using enzyme satg. conditions revealed estrone prodn. ranging 0.8-125 μmol/g protein·h. The corresponding range in host mammary tumors was 3.5-7.1 μmol/g protein·h. In human breast tumors, sulfatase activity did not correlate with the levels of estrogen receptor or progesterone receptor. Comparison of sulfatase with aromatase activity in human tumors at physiol. levels of substrate revealed estrone formation via sulfatase of 2.8 pmol estrone produced/g protein·h, whereas aromatase produced only 0.27 pmol/g protein·h. In rat mammary tumors, sulfatase activity was similar to that in human tumors, whereas aromatase activity was not detected. Thus, estrone sulfatase appears to be the enzyme primarily responsible for intratissue estrone prodn. in hormone-dependent breast carcinomas.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL2cXks1Khtrk%253D&md5=53b9e2be2e2892cc16de570f826dc443

      6. 6
        Pasqualini, J. R.; Chetrite, G.; Blacker, C.; Feinstein, M. C.; Delalonde, L.; Talbi, M.; Maloche, C. Concentrations of estrone, estradiol, and estrone sulfate and evaluation of sulfatase and aromatase activities in pre- and postmenopausal breast cancer patients J. Clin. Endocrinol. Metab. 1996, 81, 1460– 1464
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6
        Concentrations of estrone, estradiol, and estrone sulfate and evaluation of sulfatase and aromatase activities in pre- and postmenopausal breast cancer patients
        Pasqualini, J. R.; Chetrite, G.; Blacker, C.; Feinstein, M.-C.; Delalonde, L.; Talbi, M.; Maloche, C.
        Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism (1996), 81 (4), 1460-4CODEN: JCEMAZ; ISSN:0021-972X. (Endocrine Society)
        This report concerns the evaluation of various estrogens, estrone (E1), estradiol (E2), and estrone (E1S), as well as E1S-sulfatase and aromatase activities in pre- and postmenopausal women with breast cancer. The levels (in picomoles per g; mean ± SEM) of the various estrogens in the breast tissue from premenopausal patients (n = 11) are: E1, 1.4 ± 0.5; E2, 1.2 ± 0.6; and E2S, 1.2 ± 0.3. In postmenopausal patients (n = 23), the values are, resp., 1.0 ± 0.4, 1.4 ± 0.7, and 3.3 ± 1.9. These concns. of estrogens in the tumors of postmenopausal patients are significantly higher than those found in plasma. The activity of E1S-sulfatase in both pre- and postmenopausal patients was 50-200 times higher than that of aromatase. E1S-sulfatase and aromatase activities are significantly higher in post-menopausal than in cycling patients. It is concluded that despite the low levels of circulating estrogens in postmenopausal patients, the tissue concns. of these steroids are several-fold higher than those in plasma, suggesting tumor accumulation of these estrogens. The physiopathol. and clincal significance of these high levels of the various estrogens (E1, E2, and E1S) as well as sulfatase and aromatase activities in postmenopausal patients with breast cancer is yet to be explored.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK28Xit1OnsLs%253D&md5=1a694ce52708f818b8f13bc29ee20592

        Gunnarsson, C.; Olsson, B. M.; Stål, O. and Members of the Southeast Sweden Breast Cancer Group. Abnormal expression of 17-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenases in breast cancer predicts late recurrence Cancer Res. 2001, 61, 8448– 8451

        Pasqualini, J. R. The selective estrogen enzyme modulators in breast cancer: a review Biochim. Biophys. Acta 2004, 1654, 123– 143

      9. 9
        Vihko, P.; Herrala, A.; Härkönen, P.; Isomaa, V.; Kaija, H.; Kurkela, R.; Pulkka, A. Control of cell proliferation of steroids: the role of 17HSDs Mol. Cell. Endocrinol. 2006, 248, 141– 148
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        9
        Control of cell proliferation by steroids: The role of 17HSDs
        Vihko, P.; Herrala, A.; Haerkoenen, P.; Isomaa, V.; Kaija, H.; Kurkela, R.; Pulkka, A.
        Molecular and Cellular Endocrinology (2006), 248 (1-2), 141-148CODEN: MCEND6; ISSN:0303-7207. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        A review. Sex steroid hormone signaling regulates the development, growth, and functioning of the breast and the prostate and plays a role in the development and progression of cancer in these organs. The intracellular concn. of active sex steroid hormones in target tissues is regulated by several enzymes, including 17β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenases (17HSDs). Changes in the expression patterns of these enzymes may play a pathophysiol. role in malignant transformation. We recently analyzed the mRNA expressions of the 17HSD type 1, 2, and 5 enzymes in about 800 breast carcinoma specimens. Both 17HSD type 1 and 2 mRNAs were detected in normal breast tissue from premenopausal women but not in specimens from postmenopausal women. The patients with tumors expressing 17HSD type 1 mRNA or protein had significantly shorter overall and disease-free survival than the other patients. The expression of 17HSD type 5 was significantly higher in breast tumor specimens than in normal tissue. Cox multivariate analyses showed that 17HSD type 1, tumor size, and estrogen receptor alpha (ERα) had independent prognostic significance. We developed, using a LNCaP prostate cancer cell line, a model to study the malignant transformation of prostate cancer and showed that androgen-sensitive LNCaP cells are transformed into neuroendocrine-like cells when cultured without androgens and, eventually into highly proliferating androgen-independent cells. We conducted Northern hybridizations and microarrays to analyze the gene expression during these processes. Substantial changes in the expressions of steroid metabolizing enzymes occurred during the transformation process. The variations in steroid-metabolizing enzymes during cancer progression may be crucial in the regulation of the growth and function of organs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28Xis1Wgtbg%253D&md5=d48719dd79f7bb9ecd218490b979f237
      10. 10
        Simpson, E. R. Sources of estrogen and their importance J. Steroid Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2003, 86, 225– 230
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        10
        Sources of estrogen and their importance
        Simpson, E. R.
        Journal of Steroid Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (2003), 86 (3-5), 225-230CODEN: JSBBEZ; ISSN:0960-0760. (: Elsevier Science Ltd.)
        A review. In premenopausal women, the ovaries are the principle source of estradiol, which functions as a circulating hormone to act on distal target tissues. However, in postmenopausal women when the ovaries cease to produce estrogen, and in men, this is no longer the case, because estradiol is no longer solely an endocrine factor. Instead, it is produced in a no. of extra-gonadal sites and acts locally at these sites as a paracrine or even intracrine factor. These sites include the mesenchymal cells of adipose tissue including that of the breast, osteoblasts and chondrocytes of bone, the vascular endothelium and aortic smooth muscle cells, and numerous sites in the brain. Thus, circulating levels of estrogens in postmenopausal women and in men are not the drivers of estrogen action, they are reactive rather than proactive. This is because in these cases circulating estrogen originates in the extra-gonadal sites where it acts locally, and if it escapes local metab. then it enters the circulation. Therefore, circulating levels reflect rather than direct estrogen action in postmenopausal women and in men. Tissue-specific regulation of CYP19 expression is achieved through the use of distinct promoters, each of which is regulated by different hormonal factors and second messenger signaling pathways. Thus, in the ovary, CYP19 expression is regulated by FSH which acts through cAMP via the proximal promoter II, whereas in placenta the distal promoter I.1 regulates CYP19 expression in response to retinoids. In adipose tissue and bone by contrast, another distal promoter-promoter I.4-drives CYP19 expression under the control of glucocorticoids, class 1 cytokines and TNFα. The importance of this unique aspect of the tissue-specific regulation of aromatase expression lies in the fact that the low circulating levels of estrogens which are obsd. in postmenopausal women have little bearing on the concns. of estrogen in, for example, a breast tumor, which can reach levels at least one order of magnitude greater than those present in the circulation, due to local synthesis within the breast. Thus, the estrogen which is responsible for breast cancer development, for the maintenance of bone mineralization and for the maintenance of cognitive function is not circulating estrogen but rather that which is produced locally at these specific sites within the breast, bone and brain. In breast adipose of breast cancer patients, aromatase activity and CYP19 expression are elevated. This occurs in response to tumor-derived factors such as prostaglandin E2 produced by breast tumor fibroblasts and epithelium as well as infiltrating macrophages. This increased CYP19 expression is assocd. with a switch in promoter usage from the normal adipose-specific promoter I.4 to the cAMP responsive promoter, promoter II. Since these two promoters are regulated by different cohorts of transcription factors and coactivators, it follows that the differential regulation of CYP19 expression via alternative promoters in disease-free and cancerous breast adipose tissue may permit the development of selective aromatase modulators (SAMs) that target the aberrant overexpression of aromatase in cancerous breast, while sparing estrogen synthesis in other sites such as normal adipose tissue, bone and brain.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXptVemsr4%253D&md5=c1624c91faeee8db6aec04c2be84b3a2
      11. 11
        Labrie, F. All sex steroids are made intracellularly in peripheral tissues by the mechanisms of intracrinology after menopause J. Steroid Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2015, 145, 133– 138
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11
        All sex steroids are made intracellularly in peripheral tissues by the mechanisms of intracrinology after menopause
        Labrie, Fernand
        Journal of Steroid Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (2015), 145 (), 133-138CODEN: JSBBEZ; ISSN:0960-0760. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        A review. Following the arrest of estradiol secretion by the ovaries at menopause, all estrogens and all androgens in postmenopausal women are made locally in peripheral target tissues according to the physiol. mechanisms of intracrinol. The locally made sex steroids exert their action and are inactivated intracellularly without biol. significant release of the active sex steroids in the circulation. The level of expression of the steroid-forming and steroid-inactivating enzymes is specific to each cell type in each tissue, thus permitting to each cell/tissue to synthesize a small amt. of androgens and/or estrogens in order to meet the local physiol. needs without affecting the other tissues of the organism. Achieved after 500 million years of evolution, combination of the arrest of ovarian estrogen secretion, the availability of high circulating levels of DHEA and the expression of the peripheral sex steroid-forming enzymes have permitted the appearance of menopause with a continuing access to intratissular sex steroids for the individual cells/tissues without systemic exposure to circulating estradiol. In fact, one essential condition of menopause is to maintain serum estradiol at biol. inactive (substhreshold) concns., thus avoiding stimulation of the endometrium and risk of endometrial cancer. Measurement of the low levels of serum estrogens and androgens in postmenopausal women absolutely requires the use of MS/MS-based technol. in order to obtain reliable accurate, specific and precise assays.While the activity of the series of steroidogenic enzymes can vary, the serum levels of DHEA show large individual variations going from barely detectable to practically normal "premenopausal" values, thus explaining the absence of menopausal symptoms in about 25% of women. It should be added that the intracrine system has no feedback elements to adjust the serum levels of DHEA, thus meaning that women with low DHEA activity will not be improved without external supplementation. Exogenous DHEA, however, follows the same intracrine rules as described for endogenous DHEA, thus maintaining serum estrogen levels at substhreshold or biol. inactive concns. Such blood concns. are not different from those obsd. in normal postmenopausal women having high serum DHEA concns. Androgens, on the other hand, are practically all made intracellularly from DHEA by the mechanisms of intracrinol. and are always maintained at very low levels in the blood in both pre- and postmenopausal women. Proof of the importance of intracrinol. is also provided, among others, by the well-recognized benefits of aromatase inhibitors and antiestrogens used successfully for the treatment of breast cancer in postmenopausal women where all estrogens are made locally. Each medical indication for the use of DHEA, however, requires clin. trials performed according to the FDA guidelines and the best rules of clin. medicine.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXpvFWltLw%253D&md5=9cd148db461f2b020210f06f0a6e8585
      12. 12
        McNamara, K. M.; Sasano, H. The intracrinology of breast cancer J. Steroid Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2015, 145, 172– 178
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        12
        The intracrinology of breast cancer
        McNamara, Keely May; Sasano, Hironobu
        Journal of Steroid Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (2015), 145 (), 172-178CODEN: JSBBEZ; ISSN:0960-0760. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        A review. The importance of intracrinol., or in situ prodn. of steroids from circulating precursors, in breast cancer has been firmly established in estrogen actions on postmenopausal patients. Expression levels of various steroid synthesizing and/or metabolizing enzymes have been examd. in human breast cancer tissues by a no. of groups. The enzymes examd. include those capable of converting circulating DHEA-S to sex steroids (STS and 3βHSDΔ4-5 isomerase), the group of enzymes that modulate the strength of both androgens and estrogens (17βHSD family) as well as the androgenic 5αR enzymes and the estrogenic aromatase enzyme. In addn. to these DHEA-related metab. pathways, other intracrine pathways involving progesterone and cholesterol have also been examd. Some risk factors of breast cancer development, including obesity, have also been postulated to interact with steroid metabolising pathways. In this review, we aimed to summarise the current state of knowledge regarding intracrine metab. including expression levels of various enzymes and receptors, focusing particularly upon the importance of the prodn. of biol. potent steroids from circulating sulfated precursors such as DHEA-S. In addn., we attempted to summarise the factors, both steroidal and non-steroidal, involved in the regulation of these enzymes and propose future directions for research in this particular field. The concept of intracrinol. was first proposed over 20 years ago but there still remain many unanswered questions which could open new horizons for the understanding of intracrine metab. in the breast.This article is part of a Special Issue entitled 'Essential role of DHEA'.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXnslGntL8%253D&md5=4ef9d4e5963930edc03b70053c95ef0c
      13. 13
        Utsumi, T.; Yoshimura, N.; Takeuchi, S.; Maruta, M.; Maeda, K.; Harada, N. Elevated steroid sulfatase expression in breast cancers J. Steroid Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2000, 73, 141– 145
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13
        Elevated steroid sulfatase expression in breast cancers
        Utsumi, Toshiaki; Yoshimura, Noriko; Takeuchi, Shinji; Maruta, Morito; Maeda, Kotaro; Harada, Nobuhiro
        Journal of Steroid Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (2000), 73 (3-4), 141-145CODEN: JSBBEZ; ISSN:0960-0760. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
        In situ estrogen synthesis makes an important contribution to the high estrogen concn. found in breast cancer tissues. Steroid sulfatase which hydrolyzes several sulfated steroids such as estrone sulfate, dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate, and cholesterol sulfate may be involved. In the present study, the authors therefore, assessed steroid sulfatase mRNA levels in breast malignancies and background tissues from 38 patients by reverse transcription and polymerase chain reaction. The levels in breast cancer tissues were significantly increased at 1458.4 amol/mg RNA (mean) as compared with 535.6 amol/mg RNA for non-malignant tissues. Thus, increased steroid sulfatase expression may be partly responsible for local overprodn. of estrogen and provide a growth advantage for tumor cells.

      14. 14
        Utsumi, T.; Yoshimura, N.; Takeuchi, S.; Ando, J.; Maruta, M.; Maeda, K.; Harada, N. Steroid sulfatase expression is an independent predictor of recurrence in human breast cancer Cancer Res. 1999, 59, 377– 381

        Suzuki, T.; Nakata, T.; Miki, Y.; Kaneko, C.; Moriya, T.; Ishida, T.; Akinaga, S.; Hirakawa, H.; Kimura, M.; Sasano, H. Estrogen sulfotransferase and steroid sulfatase in human breast carcinoma Cancer Res. 2003, 63, 2762– 2770

      16. 16
        Billich, A.; Nussbaumer, P.; Lehr, P. Stimulation of MCF-7 breast cancer cell proliferation by estrone sulfate and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate: inhibition by novel non-steroidal steroid sulfatase inhibitors J. Steroid Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2000, 73, 225– 235
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16
        Stimulation of MCF-7 breast cancer cell proliferation by estrone sulfate and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate: inhibition by novel non-steroidal steroid sulfatase inhibitors
        Billich, Andreas; Nussbaumer, Peter; Lehr, Philipp
        Journal of Steroid Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (2000), 73 (5), 225-235CODEN: JSBBEZ; ISSN:0960-0760. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
        Steroid sulfatase (STS) regulates the formation of active steroids from systemic precursors, such as estrone sulfate and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS). In breast tissues, this pathway is a source for local prodn. of estrogens, which support the growth of endocrine-dependent tumors. Therefore, inhibitors of STS could have therapeutic potential. In this study, the authors report on substituted chromenone sulfamates as a novel class of non-steroidal irreversible inhibitors of STS. The compds. are substantially more potent (6- to 80-fold) than previously described types of non-steroidal inhibitors when tested against purified STS. In MCF-7 breast cancer cells, they inhibit STS activity with IC50 below 100 pM. Importantly, the compds. also potently block estrone sulfate-stimulated growth of MCF-7 cells, again with IC50 below 100 pM. For one compd., the authors also obsd. a lack of any estrogenic effect at high concns. (1 μM). The authors also demonstrate for the first time that STS inhibitors can block the DHEAS-stimulated growth of MCF-7 cells. Interestingly, this cannot be achieved with specific inhibitors of the aromatase, suggesting that stimulation of MCF-7 cell growth by DHEAS follows an aromatase-independent pathway. This gives further justification to consider steroid sulfatase inhibitors as potential drugs in the therapy of breast cancer.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXnvFWnsrk%253D&md5=bc48d55d2638440308400788df0cf026
      17. 17
        Obiorah, I.; Jordan, V. C. Progress in endocrine approaches to the treatment and prevention of breast cancer Maturitas 2011, 70, 315– 321

        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      18. 18
        Cuzick, J.; Sestak, I.; Forbes, J. F.; Dowsett, M.; Knox, J.; Cawthorn, S.; Saunders, C.; Roche, N.; Mansel, R. E.; von Minckwitz, G.; Bonanni, B.; Palva, T.; Howell, A. IBIS-II investigators.       19. 19
        Purohit, A.; Dauvois, S.; Parker, M. G.; Potter, B. V. L.; Williams, G. J.; Reed, M. J. The hydrolysis of estrone sulphate and dehydroepiandrosterone sulphate by human sulfatase expressed in transfected COS-1 cells J. Steroid Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1994, 50, 101– 104
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        19
        The hydrolysis of estrone sulfate and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate by human steroid sulfatase expressed in transfected COS-1 cells
        Purohit, A.; Dauvois, Sophie; Parker, M. G.; Potter, B. V. L.; Williams, G. J.; Reed, M. J.
        Journal of Steroid Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (1994), 50 (1-2), 101-4CODEN: JSBBEZ; ISSN:0960-0760.
        Whether the same or distinct steroid sulfatases (STS) are involved in the hydrolysis of alkyl and aryl steroid sulfates remains controversial. The authors have examd. the ability of a placental steroid sulfatase to hydrolyze estrone sulfate and/or dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHA-S) by expressing the enzyme in COS-1 cells. Using either intact cells or broken cell prepns., the expressed sulfatase was found to hydrolyze both estrone sulfate and DHA-S. The catalysis of estrone sulfate and DHA-S by the expressed sulfatase was almost completely abolished by the steroid sulfatase inhibitor, estrone-3-O-sulfamate. It is concluded that both alkyl and aryl steroid sulfates can be hydrolyzed by the same steroid sulfatase.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2cXlt1GmtLo%253D&md5=f534aee5fecd4be2c90f0bd0d9c8090d
      20. 20
        Thomas, M. P.; Potter, B. V. L. The structural biology of oestrogen metabolism J. Steroid Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2013, 137, 27– 49
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        20
        The structural biology of oestrogen metabolism
        Thomas, Mark P.; Potter, Barry V. L.
        Journal of Steroid Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (2013), 137 (), 27-49CODEN: JSBBEZ; ISSN:0960-0760. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        A review. Many enzymes catalyze reactions that have an estrogen as a substrate and/or a product. The reactions catalyzed include aromatization, oxidn., redn., sulfonation, desulfonation, hydroxylation and methoxylation. The enzymes that catalyze these reactions must all recognize and bind estrogen but, despite this, they have diverse structures. This review looks at each of these enzymes in turn, describing the structure and discussing the mechanism of the catalyzed reaction. Since estrogen has a role in many disease states inhibition of the enzymes of estrogen metab. may have an impact on the state or progression of the disease and inhibitors of these enzymes are briefly discussed.

      23. 23
        Hanson, S. R.; Best, M. D.; Wong, C.-H. Sulfatases: structure, mechanism, biological activity, inhibition, and synthetic utility Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2004, 43, 5736– 5763
        Google Scholar

      24. 24
        Reed, M. J.; Purohit, A.; Woo, L. W. L.; Newman, S. P.; Potter, B. V. L. Steroid sulfatase: molecular biology, regulation, and inhibition Endocr. Rev. 2005, 26, 171– 202
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        24
        Steroid sulfatase: Molecular biology, regulation, and inhibition
        Reed, M. J.; Purohit, A.; Woo, L. W. L.; Newman, S. P.; Potter, B. V. L.
        Endocrine Reviews (2005), 26 (2), 171-202CODEN: ERVIDP; ISSN:0163-769X. (Endocrine Society)
        A review. Steroid sulfatase (STS) is responsible for the hydrolysis of aryl and alkyl steroid sulfates and therefore has a pivotal role in regulating the formation of biol. active steroids. STS is widely distributed throughout the body, and its action is implicated in physiol. processes and pathol. conditions. The crystal structure of STS has been resolved, but relatively little is known about what regulates its expression or activity. Research into the control and inhibition of this enzyme has been stimulated by its important role in supporting the growth of hormone-dependent tumors of the breast and prostate. STS is responsible for the hydrolysis of estrone sulfate and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate to estrone and dehydroepiandrosterone, resp., both of which can be converted to steroids with estrogenic properties (i.e., estradiol and androstenediol) that can stimulate tumor growth. STS expression is increased in breast tumors and has prognostic significance. The role of STS in supporting tumor growth prompted the development of potent STS inhibitors. Several steroidal and nonsteroidal STS inhibitors are now available, with the irreversible type of inhibitor having a phenol sulfamate ester as its active pharmacophore. One such inhibitor, 667 COUMATE, has now entered a phase I trial in postmenopausal women with breast cancer. The skin is also an important site of STS activity, and deficiency of this enzyme is assocd. with X-linked ichthyosis. STS may also be involved in regulating part of the immune response and some aspects of cognitive function. The development of potent STS inhibitors will allow investigation of the role of this enzyme in physiol. and pathol. processes.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXjslGjtr4%253D&md5=5ea6cff3a5f23b3f31d08506c724df06
      25. 25
        Maltais, R.; Poirier, D. Steroid sulfatase inhibitors: A review covering the promising 2000–2010 decade Steroids 2011, 76, 929– 948
        Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      26. 26
        Woo, L. W. L.; Purohit, A.; Potter, B. V. L. Development of sulfatase inhibitors Mol. Cell. Endocrinol. 2011, 340, 175– 185
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        26
        Development of steroid sulfatase inhibitors
        Woo, L. W. Lawrence; Purohit, Atul; Potter, Barry V. L.
        Molecular and Cellular Endocrinology (2011), 340 (2), 175-185CODEN: MCEND6; ISSN:0303-7207. (Elsevier Ireland Ltd.)
        A review. Hydrolysis of biol. inactive steroid sulfates to unconjugated steroids by steroid sulfatase (STS) is strongly implicated in rendering estrogenic stimulation to hormone-dependent cancers such as those of the breast. Considerable progress has been made in the past two decades with regard to the discovery, design and development of STS inhibitors. We outline historical aspects of their development, cumulating in the discovery of the first clin. trial candidate STX64 (BN83495, Irosustat) and other sulfamate-based inhibitors. The development of reversible STS inhibitors and the design of dual inhibitors of both aromatase and STS is also discussed.

        Secky, L.; Svoboda, M.; Klameth, L.; Bajna, E.; Hamilton, G.; Zeillinger, R.; Jäger, W.; Thalhammer, T. The sulfatase pathway for estrogen formation: targets for the treatment and diagnosis of hormone-associated tumors J. Drug Delivery 2013, 957605

      28. 28
        Williams, S. J. Sulfatase inhibitors: a patent review Expert Opin. Ther. Pat. 2013, 23, 79– 98
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        28
        Sulfatase inhibitors: a patent review
        Williams, Spencer J.
        Expert Opinion on Therapeutic Patents (2013), 23 (1), 79-98CODEN: EOTPEG; ISSN:1354-3776. (Informa Healthcare)
        A review. Introduction: Steroid sulfatase (STS) converts sulfated hormones to free hormones of importance in hormone-dependent diseases such as breast cancer and endometriosis. Carbohydrate sulfatases degrade complex carbohydrates as part of normal cellular turnover; certain lysosomal storage disorders (LSDs) involve defective processing of sulfated glycosaminoglycans by mutant sulfatases.Areas covered: Aryl sulfamates have been developed as STS inhibitors, and STX64 and PGL2001 are under evaluation in Phase I and II clin. trials for treatment of endometrial and metastatic breast and prostate cancers and endometriosis. Dual-acting compds. have emerged that are aromatase inhibitors (AIs), selective estrogen receptor antagonists, or inhibitors of microtubule polymn. Sulfamidase inhibitors as pharmacol. chaperones to assist maturation of folding-defective mutants for the treatment of Sanfilippo type A disease are under investigation. Coverage: The patent literature after the mid-1990s.Expert opinion: The failure of STX64 in a Phase II monotherapy clin. trial should not dissuade further investigations in multidrug regimens, particularly in combination with AIs. The recent development of dual-acting compds. may enhance the potential for success in the clinic. Further investigations into aryl sulfamates are required to clarify the mol. mechanism of action; addnl., new reversible sulfatase inhibition concepts are needed for the development of pharmacol. chaperones for sulfatase LSDs.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhvVCksr3F&md5=bc07e9358b004543cb4ac5c85f578f30

        Benson, G. A.; Spillane, W. J. Sulfamic acid and its N-substituted derivatives Chem. Rev. 1980, 80, 151– 186

        Benson, G. A.; Spillane, W. J. Sulfamic acid and derivatives. In The Chemistry of Sulfonic Acids, Esters and their Derivatives; Patai, S.; Rappoport, Z., Eds.; John Wiley & Sons: New York, 1991; pp 947– 1036.

        Spillane, W.; Malaubier, J.-B. Sulfamic acid and its N- and O-substituted derivatives Chem. Rev. 2014, 114, 2507– 2586

        32
        Sulfamic Acid and Its N- and O-Substituted Derivatives
        Spillane, William; Malaubier, Jean-Baptiste
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2014), 114 (4), 2507-2586CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Sulfamic acid and its N- and O- substituted derivs. is reviewed. In the present review, the 21 yr period from 1991 to the end of 2011 is covered.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhvFeqtrrJ&md5=6e9dbf02dbb2985b70133d9f766f09a2
      33. 33
        Winum, J.-Y.; Scozzafava, A.; Montero, J.-l.; Supuran, C. T. Sulfamates and their therapeutic potential Med. Res. Rev. 2005, 25, 186– 228
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        33
        Sulfamates and their therapeutic potential
        Winum, Jean-Yves; Scozzafava, Andrea; Montero, Jean-Louis; Supuran, Claudiu T.
        Medicinal Research Reviews (2005), 25 (2), 186-228CODEN: MRREDD; ISSN:0198-6325. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
        A review. Starting from the very simple mol. sulfamic acid, O-substituted-, N-substituted-, or di-/tri-substituted sulfamates may be obtained, which show specific biol. activities which were or started to be exploited for the design of many types of therapeutic agents. Among them, sulfamate inhibitors of aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases (aaRSs) were recently reported, constituting completely new classes of antibiotics, useful in the fight of drug-resistant infections. Anti-viral agents incorporating sulfamate moieties have also been obtained, with at least two types of such derivs. investigated: the nucleoside/nucleotide human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) reverse transcriptase inhibitors, and the HIV protease inhibitors (PIs). In the increasing armamentarium of anti-cancer drugs, the sulfamates occupy a special position, with at least two important targets evidenced so far: the steroid sulfatases (STSs) and the carbonic anhydrases (CAs). An impressing no. of inhibitors of STSs of the sulfamate type have been reported in the last years, with several compds., such as 667 COUMATE among others, progressing to clin. trials for the treatment of hormone-dependent tumors (breast and prostate cancers). This field is rapidly evolving, with many types of new inhibitors being constantly reported and designed in such a way as to increase their anti-tumor properties, and decrease undesired features (for example, estrogenicity, a problem encountered with the first generation such inhibitors, such as EMATE). Among the many isoenzymes of CAs, at least two, CA IX and CA XII, are highly overexpressed in tumors, being generally absent in the normal tissues. Inhibition of tumor-assocd. CAs was hypothesized to lead to novel therapeutic approaches for the treatment of cancer. Many sulfamates act as very potent (low nanomolar) CA inhibitors. The x-ray crystal structure of the best-studied isoenzyme, CA II, with three sulfamates (sulfamic acid, topiramate, and EMATE) has recently been reported, which allowed for a rationale drug design of new inhibitors. Indeed, low nanomolar CA IX inhibitors of the sulfamate type have been reported, although such compds. also act as efficient inhibitors of isoenzymes CA I and II, which are not assocd. with tumors. A large no. of anti-convulsant sulfamates have been described, with one such compd., topiramate, being widely used clin. as anti-epileptic drug. By taking into consideration a side effect of topiramate, an anti-epileptic drug leading to wt. loss in some patients, it has recently been proposed to use this drug and related sulfamates for the treatment of obesity. The rationale of this use is based on the inhibition of the mitochondrial CA isoenzyme, CA V, involved in lipogenesis. Some sulfamates were also shown to possess potent inhibitory activity against acyl CoA:cholesterol acyltransferase, an enzyme involved in cholesterol metab. One such agent, avasimibe, is in advanced clin. trials for the treatment of hyperlipidemia and atherosclerosis. Thus, the sulfamate moiety offers very attractive possibilities for the drug design of various pharmacol. agents, which are on one hand due to the relative ease with which such compds. are synthesized, and on the other one, due to the fact that biol. activity of most of them is impressive.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXitlWhsL4%253D&md5=d9d2f31b7cdf47a11d204227813c0f2a

        Spillane, W. J.; Ryder, C. A.; Walsh, M. R.; Curran, P. J.; Concagh, D. G.; Wall, S. N. Sulfamate sweeteners Food Chem. 1996, 56, 255– 261

        Florini, J. R.; Bird, H. H.; Bell, P. H. Inhibition of protein synthesis in vitro and in vivo by nucleocidin, an antitrypanosomal antibiotic J. Biol. Chem. 1966, 241, 1091– 1098

      36. 36
        Rosenfeld, W. E. Topiramate: a review of preclinical, pharmacokinetic, and clinical data Clin. Ther. 1997, 19, 1294– 1308
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        36
        Topiramate: a review of preclinical, pharmacokinetic, and clinical data
        Rosenfeld, William E.
        Clinical Therapeutics (1997), 19 (6), 1294-1308CODEN: CLTHDG; ISSN:0149-2918. (Excerpta Medica)
        A review with 35 refs. The antiepileptic drug (AED) topiramate is a monosaccharide deriv. with a sulfamate functionality. It modulates voltage-dependent sodium conductance, potentiates GABA-evoked currents, and blocks the kainate/AMPA (α-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methylisoxazole-4-propionic acid) subtype of the glutamate receptor. Topiramate is rapidly absorbed and has linear, proportional, steady-state pharmacokinetics. It has no known clin. significant effect on plasma levels of carbamazepine, valproic acid, or phenobarbital, although it may increase plasma concns. of phenytoin in some patients. When topiramate is used with hepatic enzyme-inducing AEDs, its plasma concns. are approx. 50% lower than when it is administered alone. The efficacy of topiramate administered at 200-1000 mg/day in 2 divided doses as adjunctive therapy for partial-onset seizures has been investigated in 5 double-masked, placebo-controlled trials. The median percentage redn. in av. monthly seizure frequency from basal values was 12% for placebo, compared with 30% for the 200-mg/day group and 48% for the 400-mg/day group. At a dosage of 400 mg/day, a seizure redn. of ≥75% was seen in 22% of topiramate patients, compared with 7% of those receiving placebo; ≤9% of topiramate patients, compared with none of those receiving placebo, became seizure free. Although little addnl. efficacy was seen at dosages of 600, 800, and 1000 mg/day, doses should be individualized, because some patients may respond to higher dosages. When topiramate is combined with other AEDs, the most common side effects at dosages of 200-400 mg/day are somnolence, dizziness, ataxia, psychomotor slowing, hesitant speech, and word-finding difficulties. Most patients who experienced adverse events during the 1st 8 wk of the trials no longer experienced them by their last visit. Although there was a 1.5% incidence of renal stones that may be assocd. with carbonic anhydrase inhibition, >75% of the patients experiencing a stone continued on therapy.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

      44. 44
        Purohit, A.; Riaz, A. A.; Ghilchik, M. W.; Reed, M. J. The origin of oestrone sulphate in normal and malignant breast tissues in postmenopausal women Horm. Metab. Res. 1992, 24, 532– 536
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        44
        The origin of oestrone sulphate in normal and malignant breast tissues in postmenopausal women
        Purohit A; Riaz A A; Ghilchik M W; Reed M J
        Hormone and metabolic research = Hormon- und Stoffwechselforschung = Hormones et metabolisme (1992), 24 (11), 532-6 ISSN:0018-5043.
        Conversion of oestrone sulphate to oestrone has been suggested to make a major contribution to the level of oestrone found in breast tissues. In order to examine the ability of breast tissues to take up oestrone sulphate (E1S), 3H E1S or E1-35S was infused into postmenopausal women with advanced breast cancer. For 3 subjects infusion of 3H E1S was repeated after treatment with Danazol, a potential inhibitor of oestrone sulphatase activity. After infusion of 3H E1S significant levels of 3H E1S were detected in normal and malignant breast tissues (tissue: plasma ratios 0.14 +/- 0.13 and 0.24 +/- 0.12 respectively, mean +/- S.D., n = 5). Similar 3H E1S tissue: plasma ratios were detected after infusions of 3H E1 indicating that the 3H E1S detected in breast tissues after infusion of 3H E1S may have originated from the hydrolysis of 3H E1S in tissues other than the breast, with subsequent uptake and sulphation in breast tissues. After infusion of E1-35S no significant levels of radioactivity were detectable in normal or malignant breast tissues. Treatment with Danazol had no significant effect on tissue levels of 3H E1S or on the CRE1S E1 or MCR-E1S. It is concluded that oestrone sulphate, as such, is not taken up by breast tissues and that any contribution that oestrone sulphate makes to the oestrogen content of breast tissues will depend upon prior hydrolysis.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADyaK3s%252FosVSrtg%253D%253D&md5=426573d501507b0e9e381cfbb046f7a9

        Howarth, N. M.; Cooper, G.; Purohit, A.; Duncan, L.; Reed, M. J.; Potter, B. V. L. Phosphonates and thiophosphonates as sulphate surrogates: synthesis of estrone 3-methylthiophosphonate, a potent inhibitor of estrone sulfatase Bioorg. Med. Chem. Lett. 1993, 3, 313– 318

      49. 49
        Purohit, A.; Williams, G. J.; Roberts, C. J.; Potter, B. V. L.; Reed, M. J. In vivo inhibition of oestrone sulphatase and dehydroepiandrosterone sulphatase by oestrone-3-O-sulphamate Int. J. Cancer 1995, 63, 106– 111
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        49
        In vivo inhibition of estrone sulfatase and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfatase by estrone-3-O-sulfamate
        Purohit, A.; Williams, G. J.; Roberts, C. J.; Potter, B. V. L.; Reed, M. J.
        International Journal of Cancer (1995), 63 (1), 106-11CODEN: IJCNAW; ISSN:0020-7136. (Wiley-Liss)
        Many tumors in endocrine-sensitive tissues, such as the breast and endometrium, are hormone-dependent and the hydrolysis of estrone sulfate (EIS) to estrone by estrone sulfatase (E1-STS) is a major source of estrogen in such tumors. Estrone-3-O-sulfamate (EMATE) has been shown to be a potent E1-STS inhibitor in vitro, and in this study its ability to inhibit enzyme activity in vivo was examd. EMATE was initially administered to female rats for 7 days, after which liver E1-STS activity was measured. As EMATE also inhibits a related sulfatase in vitro, dehydroepiandrosterone sulfatase (DHA-STS), its effect on the activity of this enzyme in vivo was also investigated. DHA-STS has a pivotal role in regulating the synthesis of another steroid with potent estrogenic properties, androstenediol. Administration of EMATE almost completely inhibited liver E1-STS (99%) and DHA-STS (99%) activities and was active when given by the oral or s.c. routes. After a single dose of EMATE or following the cessation of multiple doses for 10 days, liver E1-STS activity remained inhibited (>95%) for up to 7 and 10 days, resp. Other compds., such as 4-hydroxytamoxifen and the "pure" anti-estrogen ICI 182,780, which are reported to inhibited E1-STS activity in vitro, did not inhibit activity in vivo. In a preliminary study, EMATE, when injected over a 12-day period, effectively reduced the growth of E1S-stimulated nitrosomethyl-urea-induced mammary tumors in ovariectomized rats and inhibited tumor sulfatase activity in treated animals.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXptlyqt7g%253D&md5=f812f95aeca622d0842ab0b01100f2dc
      50. 50
        Reed, M. J.; Purohit, A.; Duncan, L. J.; Singh, A.; Roberts, C. J.; Williams, G. J.; Potter, B. V. L. The role of cytokines and sulphatase inhibitors in regulating oestrogen synthesis in breast tumors J. Steroid Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1995, 53, 413– 420
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        50
        The role of cytokines and sulfatase inhibitors in regulating estrogen synthesis in breast tumors
        Reed, M. J.; Purohit, A.; Duncan, L. J.; Singh, A.; Roberts, C. J.; Williams, G. J.; Potter, B. V. L.
        Journal of Steroid Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (1995), 53 (1-6), 413-20CODEN: JSBBEZ; ISSN:0960-0760. (Elsevier)
        A review with 42 refs. Synthesis of estrogens within breast tissues makes an important contribution to the high concns. of estradiol which are found in breast tumors. The activities of the enzymes involved in estrogen synthesis, i.e., the aromatase, estradiol dehydrogenase (E2DH) and estrone sulfatase (E1-STS), can be stimulated by several growth factors and cytokines. As it is possible that some of these factors may be derived from cells of the immune system (macrophages and lymphocytes), the effects of basic fibroblast growth factor (bFGF) and interleukin-2 (IL-2), which are produced by these cells, on E2DH activity was examd. in MCF-7 cells. Estrone 3-O-sulfamate (EMATE) is a potent, irreversible, inhibitor of E1-STS. A single dose of EMATE (10 mg/kg) inhibited tissue E1-STS activity in rats by more than 95% for up to 7 days, indicating that this compd. may have considerable therapeutic potential for the treatment of breast cancer. Evidence is also reviewed that another steroid sulfatase, dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate sulfatase, may have a crucial role in regulating cytokine prodn. and that this may indirectly control tumor estrogen synthesis. Treatment of these cells with bFGF resulted in a dose-dependent increase in E2DH reductive activity whereas IL-2 was inactive at the concn. tested. To obtain further evidence that factors produced by macrophages and lymphocytes can modulate the activities of enzymes involved in estrogen synthesis, conditioned medium was collected from these cells and found to stimulate both E1-STS and E2DH activities. In addn. to understanding the control of estrogen synthesis in breast tumors an inhibitor to block the synthesis of estrone via the estrone sulfatase pathway was developed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXnt1GntLY%253D&md5=b7904f8d39ac016fd0677721b789f0fe
      51. 51
        Purohit, A.; Reed, M. J.; Morris, N. C.; Williams, G. J.; Potter, B. V. L. Regulation and inhibition of sulfatase activity in breast cancer Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 1996, 784, 40– 49
        Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      52. 52
        Sahm, U. G.; Williams, G. J.; Purohit, A.; Hidalgo Aragones, I.; Parish, D.; Reed, M. J.; Potter, B. V. L.; Pouton, C. W. Development of an oral formulation for oestrone 3-O-sulphamate, a potent sulphatase inhibitor Pharm. Sci. 1996, 2, 17– 20
        [CAS], Google Scholar
        52
        Development of an oral formulation for estrone 3-O-sulfamate, a potent sulfatase inhibitor
        Sahm, Ulrike G.; Williams, Gary J.; Purohit, Atul; Hidalgo Aragones, M. Isabel; Parish, David; Reed, Michael J.; Potter, Barry V. L.; Pouton, Colin W.
        Pharmaceutical Sciences (1996), 2 (1), 17-20CODEN: PHSCFB; ISSN:1356-6881. (Royal Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain)
        Estrone sulfatase is a key enzyme involved in estrogen synthesis in breast tumors in postmenopausal women. As breast tumors can be endocrine-dependent, it is therefore feasible that blockage of this enzyme may be of value in the treatment of such tumors. Estrone 3-O-sulfamate (EMATE) is the most potent inhibitor of estrone sulfatase activity described to date. A preliminary examn. of its physicochem. properties and the development of a self-emulsifying formulation for potential administration of EMATE by the oral route is described. A preliminary assessment of the absorption of the drug from the gut was undertaken, and pharmacol. activity, detd. as estrone sulfatase inhibition, was studied following i.v. and oral administration. A high-performance liq. chromatog. (HPLC) assay was developed to measure degrdn. of EMATE in the formulation and also its concn. in rat plasma. The drug was susceptible to degrdn., but its stability in the formulation was satisfactory when stored at either 4° or room-temp. over the time-span required for a clin. trial. Plasma EMATE concns. after 2 h were a function of the dose of drug administered orally to rats over the 10-40 mg kg-1 range. After oral administration in the self-emulsifying system, EMATE appeared to be rapidly absorbed, with the peak plasma concn. being detected at 30 min, after which plasma concns. rapidly decreased. After i.v. administration, a similar plasma EMATE concn. was detected at 1 h to that obsd. after oral administration. Rat liver sulfatase activity was almost completely inhibited (>99%) within 30 min of oral or i.v. administration of EMATE.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK28XkvFGkurc%253D&md5=5d49fe4c0a4c05f8b4fceeee06fbe929
      53. 53
        Hidalgo Aragones, M. I.; Purohit, A.; Parish, D.; Sahm, U. G.; Pouton, C. W.; Potter, B. V. L.; Reed, M. J. Pharmacokinetics of oestrone-3-O-sulphamate J. Steroid Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1996, 58, 611– 617
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        53
        Pharmacokinetics of estrone-3-O-sulfamate
        Hidalgo Aragones, M. I.; Purohit, A.; Parish, D.; Sahm, U. G.; Pouton, C. W.; Potter, B. V. L.; Reed, M. J.
        Journal of Steroid Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (1996), 58 (5/6), 611-617CODEN: JSBBEZ; ISSN:0960-0760. (Elsevier)
        The sulfatase pathway is thought to be the major route of estrogen synthesis in breast tumors in postmenopausal women. There is current considerable interest in developing a potent steroid sulfatase inhibitor to block estrogen synthesis by this route. One of the most potent inhibitors discovered so far is estrone-3-O-sulfamate (EMATE) which is active in vivo. In this study, we report the prepn. of a formulation for the administration of EMATE by the oral route. A method, using high-performance liq. chromatog. (HPLC), was also established to measure concns. of EMATE in rat plasma after its oral or i.v. administration. Using the oral formulation and HPLC assay, EMATE was readily detected in rat plasma after oral administration. Plasma EMATE concns. were related to the dose of drug administered orally over the 10-40 mg/kg range. To examine the pharmacokinetics of EMATE, the compd. (40 mg/kg, single dose) was administered either orally (in the formulation) or i.v. (in propylene glycol) with plasma samples being collected for up to 6 h. After oral administration, EMATE was rapidly absorbed, with the peak plasma concn. being detected at 30 min, after which plasma concn. rapidly decreased. After i.v. administration a plasma EMATE concn. was detected at 1 h similar to that after oral administration. The clearance of EMATE from plasma followed a bi-phasic curve, showing an initial half-life of 30 min, followed by a slower half-life of 4 h 30 min. Little evidence was obtained for any metab. of EMATE to estrone. Rat liver sulfatase activity was almost completely inhibited (>99%) within 30 min of oral or i.v. administration of EMATE.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK28XmvFajsb0%253D&md5=7891eca64cd4f6fb396ab007a115955c
      54. 54
        Purohit, A.; Froome, V. A.; Wang, D. Y.; Potter, B. V. L.; Reed, M. J. Measurement of oestrone sulphatase activity in white blood cells to monitor in vivo inhibition of steroid sulphatase activity by oestrone-3-O-sulphamate J. Steroid Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1997, 62, 45– 51
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        54
        Measurement of estrone sulfatase activity in white blood cells to monitor in vivo inhibition of steroid sulfatase activity by estrone-3-O-sulfamate
        Purohit, A.; Froome, V. A.; Wang, D. Y.; Potter, B. V. L.; Reed, M. J.
        Journal of Steroid Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (1997), 62 (1), 45-51CODEN: JSBBEZ; ISSN:0960-0760. (Elsevier)
        Formation of estrone via the sulfatase pathway is considered to be a major source of the estrogen present in breast tumors. Several inhibitors of steroid sulfatase have now been developed for use in the treatment of postmenopausal women with breast cancer. In order to be able to monitor the extent and duration of the inhibition of estrone sulfatase (E1-STS) readily, we have developed a method to measure the activity of this enzyme in white blood cells (WBCs). Hydrolysis of estrone sulfate by E1-STS in WBCs was linear with respect to time and the vol. of WBCs used. To examine whether the extent of inhibition of E1-STS activity in WBCs, by the inhibitor estrone-3-O-sulfamate (EMATE), reflected inhibition in other body tissues, activity in WBCs was compared with that in liver and spleen tissue samples from rats. Two hours after an oral dose of EMATE the extent of inhibition of E1-STS detected in WBCs was the same as in the liver. The duration of the inhibition of E1-STS by EMATE, examd. over a 1-28 day period in rats, was similar whether monitored in WBCs, liver or spleen. Measurements of E1-STS activity in WBCs were also used to examine the effectiveness of EMATE (0.5 mg/kg) in two male volunteers. E1-STS activity was rapidly inhibited and had only recovered by 27% after 1 mo. A marked decrease in the ratio of plasma dehydroepiandrosterone:dehydroepiandrosterone-sulfate (DHA:DHA-S) concns. was also detected, confirming that EMATE also inhibits DHA-STS activity. The ability to monitor the extent and duration of steroid sulfatase inhibition in WBCs will facilitate the evaluation of this new form of endocrine therapy in women with breast cancer.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXnt1emtbs%253D&md5=a9d553bc273fbf7e0b47431e729615cd
      55. 55
        Woo, L. W. L.; Lightowler, M.; Purohit, A.; Reed, M. J.; Potter, B. V. L. Heteroatom-substituted analogues of the active-site directed inhibitor estra-1,3,5(10)-trien-17-one-3-sulphamate inhibit estrone sulphatase by a different mechanism J. Steroid Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1996, 57, 79– 88
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        55
        Hetero atom-substituted analogs of the active-side directed inhibitor estra-1,3,5(10)-triene-17-one-3-sulfamate inhibit estrone sulfatase by a different mechanism
        Woo, L. W. Lawrence; Lightowler, Mark; Purohit, Atul; Reed, Michael J.; Potter, Barry V. L.
        Journal of Steroid Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (1996), 57 (1/2), 79-88CODEN: JSBBEZ; ISSN:0960-0760. (Elsevier)
        Estrogens have a pivotal role in the growth and development of hormone-dependent breast cancers. In postmenopausal women, the hydrolysis of the conjugate estrone sulfate (E1S) to estrone (E1) by the enzyme estrone sulfatase is the major source of breast tumor estrogen. Inhibitors of estrone sulfatase should therefore have considerable therapeutic potential for the treatment of hormone-dependent tumors of the breast, either as the sole agent or in conjunction with aromatase inhibitors. Several inhibitors of estrone sulfatase have now been developed of which estra-1,3,5(10)-trien-17-one-3-sulfamate (EMATE) is the most potent and also inhibits the enzyme in a time- and concn.-dependent manner, showing that it acts as an irreversible inhibitor. Analogs of EMATE in which the 3-O-atom is replaced by other heteroatoms (S and N) were prepd. and tested for inhibition against estrone sulfatase. 3-Methoxyphenylsulfamide, 4-chlorothiophenyl-S-(N,N-dimethyl)sulfamate, estra-1,3,5(10)-trien-17-one-3-sulfamide, estra-1,3,5(10)-trien-17-one-3-S-sulfamate, and estra-1,3,5(10)-trien-17-one-3-S-(N,N-dimethyl)sulfamate inhibited estrone sulfatase weakly, but none of these compds. appears to behave as a time-dependent inhibitor. A model of the mechanism of enzyme inhibition by EMATE is proposed and the authors conclude that the sulfamate bridging oxygen atom of EMATE is essential for active site-directed inhibition of estrone sulfatase.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK28XjtVegtL8%253D&md5=ce13a9f57587179a9d5a3a104fd67740
      56. 56
        Williams, G. J.; Woo, L. W. L.; Mahon, M. F.; Purohit, A.; Reed, M. J.; Potter, B. V. L. X-ray crystal structure and mechanism of action of oestrone 3-O-sulphamate, a synthetic active site-directed inhibitor of oestrone sulphatase Pharm. Sci. 1996, 2, 11– 16
        [CAS], Google Scholar
        56
        X-ray crystal structure and mechanism of action of estrone 3-O-sulfamate, a synthetic active site-directed inhibitor of estrone sulfatase
        Williams, Gary J.; Woo, L. W. Lawrence; Mahon, Mary F.; Purohit, Atul; Reed, Michael J.; Potter, Barry V. L.
        Pharmaceutical Sciences (1996), 2 (1), 11-16CODEN: PHSCFB; ISSN:1356-6881. (Royal Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain)
        Estrone 3-O-sulfamate moiety is a sulfate group surrogate relative to estrone sulfate, is the most potent estrone sulfatase inhibitor developed to date and inhibits estrone sulfatase in a time- and concn.-dependent manner, showing that it is acting as an active site-directed irreversible inhibitor. It also inhibits dehydroepiandrosterone sulfatase, the enzyme which regulates the synthesis of androstenediol. Estrone 3-O-sulfamate has also been shown to inhibit these enzymes in-vivo. The authors report its crystal structure and the synthesis and inhibitory activities of analogs in which the 3-O atom is replaced by other heteroatoms (N and S). Estrone 3-N-sulfamate and estrone 3-S-sulfamate were found to inhibit placental microsome estrone sulfatase weakly, i.e. 53% and 12%, resp., at 50 μM (compared with >99% for estrone 3-O-sulfamate), but none of these compds. appears to behave as a time-dependent inhibitor.

        Woo, L. W. L.; Purohit, A.; Reed, M. J.; Potter, B. V. L. Oestrone 3-O-(N-acetyl)sulphamate, a potential molecular probe of the active site of oestrone sulphatase Bioorg. Med. Chem. Lett. 1997, 7, 3075– 3080
